text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- British food and drink combine Grand Metropolitan emerges once again as possible buyer for Dutch BolsWessanen. (p1)
- Economic affairs minister Hans Wijers urges cabinet to cut collective tax and premium burden by Dfl 10 bn and boost investments by Dfl 4 bn a year. (p1)
- Amsterdam Stock Exchange association votes unanimously in favour of merger with EOE-option exchange. (p1)
- Dutch PTT (KPN) and textiles company Ten Cate have been awarded 1995 Henri Sijthoff Prize for the year's best financial reporting. (p1)
- Temp agency Randstad and unions reach agreement on wages for part-timers. (p2)
- Losses for shareholders in bankrupt sports-only TV channel Sport7 amount to a maximum of Dfl 280 million. (p3)
- Philips Electronics sells large TV plant in Greeneville in the U.S. (p3).
- Automation group Roccade sells its 50 pct stake in Raet to Getronics. (p3)
VOLKSKRANT
- Parliament wants to set up an independent institution to control price setting. (p2)
- Walloon government talks with steel concern Hoogovens about taking over steel firm Forges de Clabecq. (p2)
- Biochemicals and food group Gist-Brocades takes over dairy ingredients division of U.S. Cultor Food Science in New York. (p2)
- Expenditure on education in the Netherlands is relatively low, according to OECD report, Education at a Glance.
DE TELEGRAAF
- Amsterdam grants a discount on fines, if they are paid immediately. (p1)
- Real estate fund VastNed to issue new shares next spring to finance its planned takeover of rival Pays-Bas Property Fund. (p23)
- Banks are extremely wary of financing catering industry, according to catering industry association research. (p23)
- Software company AND International Publishers to get Amsterdam Stock Exchange listing on Thursday. (p25)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- French president Jacques Chirac increases pressure on Dutch to change liberal drugs policy. (p1)
- Coalition agrees on High-Speed rail link (HSL) after cabinet's willingness to invest an extra Dfl 250-300 million to remedy bottlenecks. (p1)
TROUW
- U.S. Lucent Technologies sheds 258 of the 833 jobs at its plant in Huizen. (p7)
- Motivation of Royal Dutch/Shell staff is deteriorating, due to reorganisations. (p7)
